Like the Soviets that once existed before Lenin disbanded them and murdered all of the Mensheviks.. we need our cooperative networks to be able to take over local governments, and to grow from there. We need not take on this dying carcass of an empire in war. Rather we must be well prepared with a network of interconnected collaborations that are ready to spring into action so save society the day after it implodes‚Ä¶. This is the only road to socialism here in the United States

author: @locuraromantica
text: Don't worry about your spanish Carlos, and I am very curious about your gueto spanish...Hahahah! It is going to be fine, what you don't know you'll learn it by experience. I've read your book  by the way, it was useful, I've touched the subject in the past reading books from Losurdo and others, also Fisher, but nobody as far as I can tell, have aimed for the mechanism that allows purity fetish to develop and where it orginated. I have for sure disagreements with you about the hispanic world and also about the independence movements in hispanic america but i consider your ideas and standpoints good,  and disagreements are not about the necessity of independence and revolution but about the real role liberals like Mart√≠ and Bol√≠var I do have my dfferences with you, even Bol√≠var at the end understood how he was played by the british and I think he could grasp how the power dynamics would go in hispanic america. I do think that the Spanish Empire was less cruel so toi speak than the british or the french, but not only out of principles or values but also because it was closes to the empires of ancient times...Meaning the development of capitalism, it was closer to the feudal world than the british empire later on, that influenced it, in this case for the good, since some production relations were not there. But at the end capitalism developed anyway but in the middle of a process of decay.

author: @servusprotervus6463
text:
Let me tell you something about the modern Russian state and society‚Äîsince I am part of it.

Russian society is deeply sick, and it‚Äôs been this way for a long time‚Äîstarting with the bourgeois counter-revolution of 1991, followed by the fascist coup of 1993. The country is still reeling from the plunder of the early ‚Äô90s, when the so-called ‚Äúgentlemen‚Äù in charge emptied people‚Äôs savings accounts, exchanged them for dollars, stuffed them into their own pockets, and crashed the ruble by more than 200 times overnight‚Äîblocking access to accounts in the process. Later, they printed more of this worthless currency, added it back into those accounts to cover up the theft, but of course by then the damage had already been done. 

The people are also still hurting from the so-called ‚Äúprivatization‚Äù of public property. They watched as the factories and plants they had built with their own hands were looted‚Äînew ‚Äúowners‚Äù sold the equipment, pocketed the proceeds in foreign accounts, laid off the workers, and either rented out the premises as shopping centers or abandoned them entirely. Many of those buildings are now overgrown with moss. Around 80,000 such enterprises have vanished this way. 

Then the looting became societal. A new breed of scammers emerged, mimicking the oligarchs, and began seizing privatized apartments and other property from working people through all kinds of legal and semi-legal schemes. The theft of labor and time continued through a million mechanisms: price hikes in natural monopolies, budget cuts to social rights won by earlier generations, dismantling of public institutions, elimination of vocational schools, slashing of free university placements‚Äîeffectively ending free higher education. A massive number of medical facilities were shut down. Maternity benefits were reduced, pension ages raised, subsidies eliminated. In rural areas alone (not counting towns), over the last 30 years they‚Äôve closed: 15,600 cultural centers, 4,300 libraries, 22,000 kindergartens, and 14,000 schools. All of this is labor‚Äîvalue created by the hands of working people, their time‚Äîwasted. 

No wonder people became hardened. They stopped trusting one another and themselves. Then they raised children in this atmosphere of bitterness. Any society, anywhere in the world, would start to fall apart under such trauma. And that‚Äôs the kind of society we live in now. That‚Äôs the kind of individuals who make it up. People resentful of everyone around them because of their own misfortunes. Uneducated‚Äîbecause they lack access to quality education. They don‚Äôt understand the reasons they‚Äôre in this situation, and so they direct their anger outward. I think the scale of trauma that society inflicted on itself‚Äîout of laziness and refusal to grow when the opportunity existed‚Äîcan hardly be overstated. That‚Äôs the root of the illness. People are angry at each other. They can‚Äôt reach the real culprits‚Äîthe elites‚Äîbecause they lack the means and, more importantly, class consciousness. So they take it out on their neighbors, who are just as destitute. Instead of uniting and giving the ruling class a proper kick, they lash out sideways.  

As for the war in Ukraine, it‚Äôs important to distinguish between the fascist propaganda of the Russian ruling class and their actual motives. The propaganda says Russia is fighting against Western imperialism. Fine. But if we‚Äôre Marxists, can we really afford to talk about good versus bad imperialisms? Power in Russia belongs to imperialists too‚Äîarguably the most chauvinistic kind. They may be economically weaker than their Western counterparts, but that doesn‚Äôt make them any less imperialist. 

This war is imperialist in nature, like all wars of this kind‚Äîwaged over markets. In our case, it‚Äôs about Ukraine‚Äôs hydrocarbon transit market, through which Europe once relied on Russian gas. The second goal‚Äîwhich reflects the specifics of post-Soviet capitalist states‚Äîis to grab hold of the Soviet-era means of production in Ukraine that survived privatization and still generate significant profits. Just ask Russian oligarchs Yurchenko and Tkachev‚Äîthey‚Äôre not shy about it. Look them up. Check what assets they hold in Ukraine.

Our goal as Marxists is to help the working class unite and struggle, to prepare for the next socialist revolution ‚Äî not to support one imperialist against another. In this war, as in any other imperialist war, only the ruling class profits, while workers are killed and lose their health. The war must be stopped, and the only way to stop it is to overthrow the masters‚Äô rule in the aggressor country. That is the direction our propaganda should take.

Unfortunately there will always be 100's of millions humans willing to brutalize good people because their masters tell them to and give them the monopoly money. Always been that way since the scam was invented. People don't have good solutions and neither communism nor socialism are solutions but just part of the problem. As long as the parasites exist the host will suffer and the host will suffer as long as he refuses to get rid of the parasites.

replies.author: @servusprotervus6463
replies.text:
‚Äã@alistairpage-mcgill2723I don‚Äôt feel hatred toward the Russian elites, nor toward any other elites. There‚Äôs no place for hate here. The bourgeois world runs on agreements between elites ‚Äî and they keep deceiving each other anyway. What do these agreements mean for the working class? Nothing.
Elites live off our labor. Our task is to remove them.

In this conflict, only working people die and lose their health, while the elites on both sides grow richer. This war isn‚Äôt against Western imperialism ‚Äî it was made by imperialists themselves, because they need new orders for their production. Construction companies get contracts to rebuild destroyed cities. Medical equipment and pharmaceutical industries are thriving. Even outdoor gear production grows thanks to war. And of course, the military industry faces no competition at all.

replies.author: @servusprotervus6463

replies.author: @chombers
replies.text: uses the em dash frequently because it's a common punctuation mark in its vast training data, where it serves as a way to simulate natural speech, add emphasis, or insert a parenthetical thought. This pattern stems from the many human writers who utilized the em dash in the texts AI was trained on, leading the AI to adopt it as a default stylistic choice to mimic human expression and add a sense of flow and rhythm.
